metadata.case_name: Maulana Abdul Shakoor v. Rikhab Chand Jain

facts.text: Appellant Maulana Abdul Shakoor elected to Council of States by Electoral College of Ajmer (30 members State Legislature); received 19 votes against 7 for respondent Rikhab Chand Jain; total valid votes 26, 3 invalid.
Result published in Official Gazette on March 31, 1956.
Respondent filed election petition on May 2, 1956 under s.81 Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Notification issued February 17, 1956: nominations February 28 to March 1, 1956; scrutiny March 5, 1956; polling March 22, 1956.
Appellant filed two nomination papers on February 28, 1956 and third on March 1, 1956.
Respondent filed nomination papers on March 1, 1956.
On March 5, 1956, respondent objected to appellant's nominations mainly on ground of holding office of profit under Government.

Returning Officer on March 6, 1956 rejected two nomination papers of February 28, 1956 but accepted third of March 1, 1956, as under Durgah Khwaja Saheb Emergency Provisions Act, 1950 (XVII of 1950) in force till February 29, 1956 appellant held office of profit under Government, but from March 1, 1956 under Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 (XXXVI of 1955) he no longer did.

Election Tribunal by majority order dated January 31, 1957 held appellant held office of profit under Government on March 1, 1956 hit by Art.102(1)(a) Constitution; set aside election, declared respondent elected on thrown away votes contention.
Election Tribunal Chairman dissented, held on March 1, 1956 appellant no longer held office of profit under Government; election valid.
Tribunal unanimously held two nomination papers of February 28, 1956 invalid as appellant held office of profit then.

Appellant held appointment as mohatmin (manager) of Madarsa Durgah Khwaja Saheb Akbari, honorary from February 28, 1955 by Administrator of Durgah Khwaja Saheb; paid Rs.100 per month from May 1955 described as salary/honorarium.
Madarsa Durgah Khwaja Saheb Akbari is school for Persian, Arabic, Muslim theology; before 1951 managed by Government of Nizam of Hyderabad; 1951 taken over by Durgah Committee.
Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1936 (XXIII of 1936): management vested in Durgah Committee, body corporate; s.11(f) power to appoint servants.

Replaced by Durgah Khwaja Saheb Emergency Provisions Act, 1950 (XVII of 1950) till February 29, 1956: Committee superseded, management vested in Administrator appointed by Central Government under control of Central Government.

Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 (XXXVI of 1955) assented October 14, 1955, came into force March 1, 1956: administration vested in Committee (body corporate, 5-9 Hanafi Muslims appointed by Central Govt); s.8 Govt power to supersede; s.9 Nazim (administrator) appointed by Central Govt in consultation with Committee, ex-officio secretary, salary from Durgah funds; Committee acts through Nazim; s.11(i) power to appoint/suspend/dismiss servants; s.20 bye-laws for duties/powers of employees, approved by Central Govt.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant was holding an office of profit under the Government of India on March 1, 1956, such that his nomination paper was invalid under Art. 102(1)(a) of the Constitution.
Whether the two nomination papers filed on February 28, 1956 were valid (noted as unnecessary if March 1 paper valid).
Whether votes for appellant were thrown away votes, entitling respondent to be declared elected.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appointment as manager of school neither an office nor office of profit nor under the Government.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 102(1)(a) Constitution; Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955

respondent_arguments.text: Even under 1955 Act, appellant held office of profit under Government as Committee appointed by Govt, Nazim appointed by Govt, Govt power to supersede/remove members, make bye-laws for employees.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 102(1)(a) Constitution; Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 ss.4,5,6,8,9,11,20

respondent_arguments.text: Votes for appellant thrown away; respondent received majority valid votes.

court_reasoning.text: Assumes appellant held office of profit; controversy whether under Government of India attracting Art.102(1)(a). Difference in language: Art.102(1)(a) unlike Arts.58(2),66(4) excludes office under local/other authority subject to Govt control.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Committee is statutory body corporate with perpetual succession; servants not holders of office under Govt merely because appointed by Govt-appointed Committee or removable indirectly.

court_reasoning.text: Tests for office under Govt: appointment/continuation/dismissal by Govt at discretion, payment from Govt revenues; appellant appointed by Administrator (under Committee post-1955 Act), paid from Durgah funds, dismissible only by Committee per statute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No direct Govt appointment/removal/payment; power over Committee/bye-laws does not convert Committee servants into Govt office holders.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Shivnandan Sharma (industrial dispute case on bank servants); election cases fact-specific.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant servant of statutory body, not Govt servant.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide Feb 28 nominations or thrown away votes as March 1 nomination valid.

holdings.text: On March 1, 1956, appellant not holding office of profit under Government of India; nomination valid, election valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule on servants employed by Govt servant for Govt work inapplicable; appellant not employed by Govt servant or paid from Govt revenues.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification for office of profit under Govt of India/State for Parliament members; contrast with President/VP disqualifications including authorities under Govt control.

statutes_cited.name: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1936
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior management by Committee, body corporate with power to appoint servants.

statutes_cited.name: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Emergency Provisions Act, 1950 (XVII of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Superseded Committee, vested management in Central Govt-appointed Administrator under Govt control; in force till Feb 29, 1956.

statutes_cited.name: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 (XXXVI of 1955)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vested administration in Govt-appointed Committee (body corporate) acting through Nazim; powers over servants via s.11(i); bye-laws under s.20; in force from March 1, 1956.

statutes_cited.name: Religious Endowments Act, 1863 (XX of 1863)
statutes_cited.relevance: Pre-1936 administration by Chief Commissioner-constituted committee.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of majority Election Tribunal dated January 31, 1957 set aside; appellant's election declared valid.

key_quotes.text: "Merely because the Committee or the members of the Committee are removeable by the Government of India or the Committee can make bye-laws prescribing the duties and powers of its employees cannot in our opinion convert the servants of the Committee into holders of office of profit under the Government of India."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning distinguishing statutory body servants from Govt office holders.

key_quotes.text: "The power of the Government to appoint a person to an office of profit or to continue him in that office or revoke his appointment at their discretion and payment from out of Government revenues are important factors in determining whether that person is holding an office of profit under the Government"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test applied to find no Govt office of profit.
